instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
Liquid damage near SMC region and <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>. <CAPACITOR>C7092</CAPACITOR> area. No green light on this.

PP3v42 - 2.936V
DCIN - 15.4V
PPBUS - 8.18V

PP3V42 in diode is .303

SMC had some damage by <CAPACITOR>C5010</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5017</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5007</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5008</CAPACITOR>.

Slight short in PP3V42?

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> shorted to ground? Very common for one of those tiny guys to short and cause 2.9 volts on PP3v42.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message: Will check into that. Thanks a lot man. Have a good night.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
You don't have direct overcurrent situation on 3V42 power rail.
Should be some component connected to this line; i.e. SMC, or mentioned small caps from <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> line.
There are also other chips connected, like <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, etc...

First check correct value for <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96.
Also check for short, or low value at pin 1/<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and pin 8/<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message: Took <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> diode measurement @ <CAPACITOR>C5010</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C5017</CAPACITOR> and got around .300 which was a bit lower than .510 that I get on a working board. Replaced those components and diode measurement was still at .300 on <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL>. So I reflowed the SMC and diode measurement is now @ .475 on <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL>.  Green light is back and board turns on. Only thing is that it turns off while booting to ssd and may or may not turn back on right away. This occurs with AC or Battery power. The last time this occured I hit the board with some hot air and it turned on. This however could just be coincidence. Looks like I will be doing some more measuring in tha AM. Thanks for your help, its greatly appreciated guys.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
In this case I recommend you to reball the SMC.
Its reaction after heat denotes accumulated crap underneath.
You can try first to put good flux and heat SMC untill 180-20 degrees.
No need to melt the balls, just to burn the crap.

You may also need to apply the same process for PCH/CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
Hi, SMC has already been changed from donor. Same issue present. I will report that pad "93" of <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> is in very poor condition. Maybe this isn't making good connection with new SMC?? I do have 1.2 V on <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> from <CAPACITOR>C5011</CAPACITOR>, 13.

Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
That 1V2 voltage comes from pin 93 of SMC; so yes, there is good contact.

"You may also need to apply the same process for PCH/CPU"
Possibly crap there, if the board reacts to heat.

Which signals did you check when the board doesn't want to turn on?
Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
Hi!
I went along and did the cleanup under PCH/CPU and that resolved the turning on issue, but it is still shutting down at random times during boot. I have found that this happens when ANYTHING is plugged into the KB/TP connector. I have tried new cables and trackpads and keyboards. The connector looks ok but I am going to change it anyway. If that does not resolve the issue then most likely issue with one of the _s4 lines? Thanks guys, have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
Possibly crap on the power button.
Disconnect keyboard only, from trackpad circuitry.
Start the machine with <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR> pads, or connect only charger (no battery).
If it works good with only trackpad, then power button is the culprit.
You can also monitor <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal, when keyboard connected.
It should stay (steady) at 3.3V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
Hi, the results I posted was with KB disconnected from trackpad... New trackpad and cable as well.
Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
Okay, so replacing KB connector resolved the issue. Thanks!


Quick question if you can. How does <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> work and how is it related to pulling PP3V42 down. In other words how did you know to check there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> is a voltage generated by SMC for internal use.
Is available outside only to connect few caps for better stability.
An overcurrent there (caused by low resistance to ground) can be reflected on the 3V42 line, as is the main power rail of SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage - No green Light
